title: Staying safe online
summary: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
intro: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
text:
Staying safe online
Online safety is about being aware of possible issues you could come across whilst using the internet.
You can protect your information by taking some precautions. This guide contains links to resources to help you learn about online safety.

title: Staying safe online
summary: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
intro: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
text:
Online Privacy
Covering your tracks online
Did you know every time you use the internet, your browser (the software that allows you to find and view websites) stores a record of where you’ve been online? Your browser history includes:
Search history  - a list of the pages you’ve looked at and the files you’ve downloaded
Cookies - files called cookies which remember your settings for different sites to personalize your experience
Saved data - such as passwords and address autofill
Deleting your Internet browsing history
You can improve your privacy by deleting your internet browsing history. But you need to be careful because:
deleting cookies will also get rid of stored passwords for online accounts
clearing your history could make someone more suspicious
Try only to remove information about the websites you want to keep private. You can find out how to do that on:
Google Chrome
Safari
Internet Explorer
Mozilla Firefox
Opera
Microsoft Edge
Password security
Passwords protect your devices or accounts by keeping your information private and safe. They must be easy for you to remember but hard for others to guess or break. If someone discovers your password, they could gain access to sensitive information, including your financial data.
We have provided links below to check your password strength or learn more about password safety.
How Secure Is My Password? | Password Strength Checker
Three random words - NCSC.GOV.UK

links.text: How Secure Is My Password? | Password Strength Checker
links.context: How Secure Is My Password? | Password Strength Checker

title: Staying safe online
summary: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
intro: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
text:
Using email safely
Most organisations ask you for your email address when purchasing goods or services, but protecting your email is important as this is where most of your personal information is stored.
Do not open an attachment unless you expect it, AND know who it is from.
If you receive an attachment from someone you don't know, delete it immediately without opening it.
Make sure you never send you to send your bank details to anyone in an email. This isn’t a secure way to send financial details; online shops and banks would not ask you to do this.
For more information, see:
Cyber Aware - NCSC.GOV.UK
How to set up an email account | Age UK |

links.text: How to set up an email account | Age UK |
links.context: How to set up an email account | Age UK |

title: Staying safe online
summary: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
intro: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
text:
Staying safe on social media
Being connected to social media sites is a great way to stay in touch with your friends, family and the latest news. it’s important to learn about privacy settings and how to keep your personal information safe.
To stay safe on social media, remember:
Set your profiles to private. Think carefully about what you post online and who you want to see it.
Remember, anything you post can be shared.
Switch off your location.
Keep your contacts up-to-date and relevant.
Block anyone who bothers you.
Protect your identity.
For more information, see:
Social Media: how to use it safely - NCSC.GOV.UK
Communication & Social Networking - Get Safe Online

title: Staying safe online
summary: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
intro: Being safe online can be tricky for us all, but it’s important to know that you can learn how to protect yourself.
text:
Staying safe while online shopping and banking
Shopping and banking online is convenient, can save you money and help you keep track of your finances. Find out how to stay safe while shopping and banking online.
Online Shopping
Shopping online can be useful and sometimes save you money, but it’s important to use safe, genuine sites.
Check for the https://
Padlock info
Remember, sometimes, if the offer looks too good to be true, it usually is
For more information, see here:
How to stay safe online as an older person - Age UK
Shopping, Banking & Payments - Get Safe Online
Shopping online securely - NCSC.GOV.UK
Getting your money back if you paid by card or PayPal - Citizens Advice
Online Banking
Online banking is a convenient way to keep track of your finances 24/7 whilst at home or away.
Here are some useful links to help you stay safe when using your banking app or website. Your bank will usually have its own advice on how to bank safely.
Online banking for older people - Age UK

title: Keeping children safe online
summary: Being online can help children learn new things, have fun and make new friends. However, there are safety issues to consider.
intro: Being online can help children learn new things, have fun and make new friends. However, there are safety issues to consider.
text:
Below are some resources to learn how to keep your child safe whilst online.
NSPCC- keeping children safe online
Together we can make sure it’s safe for every child to go online. We’re here to support parents with online safety advice,
Find out more
Google - Be Internet Legends
This is a new offering from Google that is aimed at ensuring kids understand how to be safe online.  There are also tools for Schools and Parents to use.
Find out more
Barnardos - Keeping children safe online
Every child deserves to feel safe online – and we all have a part to play. Find out more about online safety from the experts.
Find out more
Internet Matters
Children deserve a safe digital world. Find information and safety settings for your child's devices and apps, along with guidance to tackle online issues they may face.
Find out more

title: Digital connectivity
summary: Digital connectivity is the term for mobile or fixed connections to the Internet. It is essential if you want to access products and services online. Find out how you can access the internet here.
intro: Digital connectivity is the term for mobile or fixed connections to the Internet. It is essential if you want to access products and services online. Find out how you can access the internet here.
text:
WIFI
Free Public Wi-Fi is available in all our
Knowsley Libraries
. Our library staff are available to show you how to connect your device or you can use a secure library PC to access sites. Call into one of our libraries for more details.
Social Tariffs - what is this?
Social Tariffs is the term used for discounted rates of broadband or mobile deals available to people who claim certain benefits.
Find out more information below and check if you qualify
Social tariffs: Cheaper broadband and phone packages | Ofcom
Discounted Internet (Social Tariffs) | Liverpool City Region Combined Authority
Disconnection of the landline phones
The traditional landline phone service is due to be switched off by 2027. Find out more below
UK transition from analogue to digital landlines | GOV.UK
Digital Voice and the landline switch-off: what it means for you | Which?
The future of fixed telephone services | Ofcom

title: Digital access skills and training
summary: With the online world rapidly expanding, it is vital to have the right skills to navigate it confidently. Find out how to access support from your local library and other organisations.
intro: With the online world rapidly expanding, it is vital to have the right skills to navigate it confidently. Find out how to access support from your local library and other organisations.
text:
Support from Knowsley Libraries
Knowsley Library Service is here to bridge the digital divide, empowering everyone, from beginners to seasoned users, with the knowledge and support they need to thrive in the digital age.
Knowsley Libraries have PCs available for you to use and people who can help you to get online.
See below for a list of all our local libraries:
Halewood library
Huyton library
Kirkby library
Prescot library
Stockbridge Village library
If you need to telephone one of our libraries, dial 0151 443 3734 and choose which branch you wish to be directed to.
If you are unsure which library is closest to you, find out
here
.
Each library organises weekly
Tea & Tech sessions
, which are free drop-in events to help you learn some basic skills. They are ideal for beginners; there is no need to book.
You can also access a free digital 1-2-1 support session by filling out the form
here
or asking in your local library.
Visit the Knowsley Libraries website
Learning or improving your online skills
There are plenty of organisations and places to learn online skills or improve online skills:
Knowsley FACE – Family & Community Education
Knowsley FACE – Family & Community Education offers digital support to anyone looking to search for or apply for jobs online. They also many other services to help residents build their skills and qualifications.
Find out more
Digital Inclusion | Liverpool City Region Combined Authority
As a city region, we are committed to ensuring that our residents have access to the skills and support needed to participate in an ever-evolving digital world fully. Find out about the support that’s on offer.
Find out more
Computer training courses - IT training services | Age UK
Many local Age UKs offer computer training for older people. These courses explain things clearly and in plain English to help you get online.
Find out more
AbilityNet
Established in 1998, AbilityNet is a pioneering UK charity transforming the lives of older and disabled people and working with organisations of all types and sizes to build a digital world that is accessible to all.
Find out more
Good Things Foundation
Good Things Foundation is a leading charity on a mission to fix the digital divide.
Find out more
Jargon Busters
The language used on the Internet can be new and confusing. Below are some jargon busters to help you better understand the terms used.
BT - Techie terms - jargon buster
Sometimes you can get bogged down in all the jargon when learning about something new. Check out this jargon buster for some simple explanations of techie terms.
Find out more
Get Safe Online - Glossary
Get Safe Online offer a glossary of digital and tech-related terms that is easy to understand.
Find out more

title: Contacting the council online
summary: Knowsley Council uses different methods of online contact, such as live chat, online forms and email.
intro: Knowsley Council uses different methods of online contact, such as live chat, online forms and email.
text:
Online Chat
Online chat is quick and easy to use and is becoming more popular with our residents. The service is available whenever you see this sign.
At the start of your enquiry, we use a virtual chatbot called VIK, which guides you to pages on our website that may resolve your enquiry.
If VIK cannot resolve your enquiry, you have the option to chat with a member of our customer service team.
Online Forms
Many services offer an online form to report, book, or apply for services. These forms can be found throughout our website, at the top of our homepage on a desktop, or in the menu area on a mobile device.
Sending your enquiry this way directs you to the correct service and saves you time.
Email
Depending on the enquiry type, you may be offered the option to email the service directly.
Emails that are available will be included on the webpage.
